moves.2. d4: The Smith-Morra Gambit, usual for Morphy, because he plays the Sicilian a lot.
moves.2... cxd4 3. Nf3 Nc6: Puts more pressure on the square d4 and protects the pawn.
moves.4. Nxd4: White captures it anyway since the Q is protecting the N.
moves.5... d6: This is better than ...a6; but even now the King's Bishop is shut in, and the Queen's Pawn rendered weak.
moves.6. Bf4: Correctly played, compelling the advance of the e-Pawn, which leaves the Queen's Pawn weak and unsupported.
moves.6... e5 7. Be3 f5: ...a6 would have been sounder play, but even then the game would have been in favor of the first player.
moves.12... Nd4 13. Nxf6+ d5: If the Bishop had been interposed, White would have taken it, checking; and on Knight retaking have played Nd5 discovering check, and won without difficulty.
moves.14. Bxd5+ Kg6: Had the Queen captured the Bishop, White would have taken with the Knight, discovering check, and have remained eventually with a Pawn ahead and a winning position.
moves.15. Qh5+ Kxf6 16. fxe3: Ne8+, seemingly a good move, is only in appearance, as Black might have taken it when placed there; and on White taking Queen, have answered with ...Bb4+, obtaining a winning game.
moves.16... Nxc2+ 17. Ke2: Black Resigns, A wonderful game Played by Morphy.
